Prompt.Prompt:
The following are what is known as FEKL Statements. They are used to define a conceptual schema.

==============Examples==============
Cinema IS A CONCEPT
Film IS AN ENTITY TYPE
Satellite IS A CONCEPT
Satellite HAS LONG DESCRIPTION "A body that orbits a planet"
Person IS AN ENTITY TYPE
Section IS AN ENTITY TYPE
Cinema IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Id
Film IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Id
Person IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Id
Section IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Name
Row IS WHERE Cinema has RowNr
Seat IS WHERE Cinema has RowNr has Letter
Adult IS A KIND OF Person
Teenager IS A KIND OF Person
Child IS A KIND OF Person
Session IS WHERE Film has DateTime has Cinema
Session IS OBJECTIFIED
Session IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Film, DateTime, Cinema
Booking IS WHERE Person has Session
Booking IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Person, Session
Booking IS OBJECTIFIED
BookingHasSeat IS WHERE Booking has Seat
BookingHasSeat IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Booking, Seat
Cinema has AT MOST ONE CinemaName
Film has AT MOST ONE Name
Company HAS LONG DESCRIPTION "A commercial business"
Person has AT MOST ONE Age
Person has AT MOST ONE DateOfBirth
Person has ONE LoginName
Seat has AT MOST ONE Section_Name
Row IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Cinema, RowNr
Seat IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Row, Letter
Seat references Section
==============End of Examples================
==============Training==========================
Background for you to learn from:

FEKL is used to define Object Types/Entities, Relationships (with predicates), and Constraints.

- The FEKL Statement, "Person IS A CONCEPT", is for the keyword, Person;
- The FEKL Statement, "Cinema IS AN ENTITY TYPE", is for the keyword, Cinema;
- The FEKL Statement, "Seat references Section" is for a relationship;
- The FEKL Statement, "Person IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Id" is for entity identification;
- The FEKL Statement, "Seat has AT MOST ONE Section Name" is a non-mandatory many to one relationship;
- The sentence: Each cinema subservice shall have at least one row, resolves to the FEKL Statement, "Cinema has AT LEAST ONE Row";
- The sentence: Each person travels to at most one city, resolves to the FELK Statement, "Person travels to AT MOST ONE City";
- The sentence: "Each film shall be uniquely identified by exactly one film id", resolves to "Film IS IDENTIFIED BY ITS Id";
- The sentence: "Each film has one film name", resolves to "Film has ONE Film Name";
- The sentence: "Child is a subtype of person" resolves to "Child IS A KIND OF Person";
- The sentence: "Person has subclass teenager" resolves to "Teenager IS A KIND OF Person"
- The sentence: "Person has property, LoginName" resolves to "Person has AT MOST ONE Login Name";
- The sentence: "Session is described as Cinema is showing Film on DateTime" resolves to "Session IS WHERE Cinema is showing Film on Date Time".

IMPORTANT: For keywords/entity names, use Pascal Case with a space between words. E.g. "First Name".

IMPORTANT:  Remember "Name" is rarely used on its own. When you have to use "Name", pair it with the entity name, "<Entity Name> Name". e.g. "Company Name". E.g. "Company has ONE Company Name", or "Person has AT MOST ONE Middle Name".

IMPORTANT: Restrict "IS WHERE" type FEKL Statements to ternary or greater relationships, not binary relationships. E.g "Person has First Name" is a binary relationship, "Session IS WHERE Cinema is showing Film on Date Time" is a ternary relationship.

Hint: You can use coreference, to pull FEKL Statements from between sentences;
Hint: "Person has firstName" resolves to "Peron has First Name";
Hint: Remember to pull descriptions into a "HAS LONG DESCRIPTION" FEKL Statements where you can.

- All Keywords are in Pascal Case, with a space betwen words;
- All predicates are in lowercase (e.g. 'has','is in');
IMPORTANT: Remember to get as many "LONG DESCRIPTION" FEKL Statements as possible.
==============End of Training===================

==============Your Task===================
You are a world class Business Analyst, doing FEKl Statement knowledge extraction from the following text to create a conceptual schema.
- Only return the FEKL Statements from the text below.
- Analyse and extract FEKL Statements for keywords, concept classification, entity type definition, entity type identification, descriptions, subtypes and relationships from only the text below:
Heres the text to analyse:

Pull out the business/product/engineering noun or noun-phrases (i.e. multi-word keywords are okay) with a space between each words, one noun phrase/noun per line, in Pascal Case with a space between each word of the Pascal Case, and in singular form. Return just the noun phrase/noun keywords and no other embelishment or explanation please. No plurals. For TLAs (three letter acronyms)...expand those where you can. Hint: We are creating a database, so noun/noun phrase keywords are going to be table names.

Operate on the text below:

Identify all the noun/noun-phrase keyword (multi-word keywords are okay) with a space between words, and present them in in Pascal Case, and in singular form, within their respective Fact Types Readings, which are defined as relationships that you have identified in the text.
Return the Fact Types Readings one per line in your response, in the form, "Person has First Name", or "Part is in Bin in Warehouse", and no other embellishment or explanation please.
No plurals for nouns/keywords.
For TLAs (three letter acronyms)...expand those.
Hint: We are creating a database, so the Fact Types Readings define the relations of the database.
Hint: You can use coreference, to pull FEKL Statements from between sentences;
Hint: "Person has firstName" resolves to "Peron has First Name";
Hint: Remember to pull descriptions into a "HAS LONG DESCRIPTION" FEKL Statements where you can.

Return the fact types readings by themselves, no need to return the nouns/noun-phrase keywords separately.

If it makes more sense to have a type for a pronoun/keyword, use the type of the pronoun as the noun/noun-phrase keyword.

Where you can identify the cardinality of a relationship, include that in the Fact Type Reading in the form, "<noun/noun phrase> has ONE <noun/noun-phrase>", or "<noun/noun-phrase> drives AT LEAST ONE <noun/noun-phrase>", etc. Options are, ONE, AT LEAST ONE, AT MOST ONE, ANY NUMBER OF

All Keywords are in Pascal Case, with a space betwen words.

All predicates are in lowercase (e.g. 'has','is in')

Operate on the text below:
